Then fill your furnace to the mouth with charcoal, heaped to the top, and let it glow for a while, and always maintain the heat even, without letting the charcoal diminish. And for that purpose, make sure that the furnace is heaped full brim and maintain it like this for one day. The first experiment I made only produced a yellow mass like minium alone when vitrified, with gold grains, in a mass at the bottom. Try cemented gold together with antimony.
top-left If you need more heat, put around the mouth of the glowing furnace some tiles one against the other in order to make the heat reverberate.

Topaz
The same dose is used for all jewels, which is one weight of calcined pebbles with three weights of minium, all pounded separately in a copper mortar for emeralds, and in an iron mortar for topazes or amber color, with pestles of the same matter as the mortars. Emeralds and topazes need to be heated at the same temperature, and for an hour and a half, otherwise they could be burnt. Rubies need more time and stronger heat, and to be colored with gold leaf. I believe that for rubies pumice stone or fire-stone would be better. See enamels. Instead of pebbles, try also to mix pieces of colored glass or enamels. If the mass is not colored enough, pound it further in the iron mortar.
left-middle Slightly burnt tartar mixed in makes beautiful yellow, but not much is needed. Sand also makes it more yellow.

Salt for melting
Mix some saltpeter and common salt and melt them together and throw them onto copper, molte or "en bain", which purifies it and makes it run marvellously. First you need to decrepitate [?] ordinary salt, which means holding it over strong heat until it crackles no more; or to melt it better, in an air-furnace.
